Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Galaxy Growth in Different Environments in the Early Universe from z=1.9 to 3.5
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will assemble optical and infrared observations of hundreds of thousands of galaxies. The observations pick out galaxies about 10 to 12 billion years back in time. This period is known to be one of hectic change for galaxies. The team will study how these changes depend on whether a galaxy has many neighbors, or no neighbors at all. This important topic could not be studied before because not enough observations were available. The team will release their assembled catalog to the public. Senior team members will train junior members. The team will give public talks, offer residential workshops to teachers and develop a three-dimensional show for a children's science museum.

In a tour de force, the team will combine data from five deep, wide-area galaxy surveys that include both photometry and integral-field-unit spectroscopy. They will use the combined data to study galaxy evolution over the full range of galactic environments at redshifts z ~ 1.9 to 3.5. These are key redshifts for galaxy evolution, as they probe the assembly of massive galaxies, the peaks in star formation and black-hole accretion, and the collapse of the largest proto-clusters of galaxies. The team will amass photometry for about 600,000 galaxies and spectroscopy for about 260,000 galaxies. Using this dataset, the team will conduct statistically meaningful analyses that were heretofore impossible.

Performance_Institution.Name: Astronomy Department at the University of Texas at Austin

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research program has produced important results on how galaxies -- the building blocks on the Universe --  build their stars and dark matter content across different environments during the early cosmic epochs when the Universe was less than 25% of its present-day age. This is an important epoch when the star formation and black hole growth in galaxies peaked and when the most massive bound structures (proto-clusters) in the Universe formed. A major strength of this program is that it explores one of the largest sample of massive galaxies observed to date over a very wide area and within a humongous volume. The program leverages data collected from NASA space-based facilities and ground-based telescopes across the world, including the McDonald Observatory in Texas, and it analyzes the resulting big data using the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC). This research program has provided important opportunities for faculty, PhD students, undergraduate students, and postdoctoral fellows to conduct cutting-edge research, enhance the reputation of Texas astronomy, and develop big data computational skills for the greater benefit of society. The results have been published and disseminated worldwide. 

This program has also provided nationally-recognized professional development workshops for secondary school teachers in order to enhance their knowledge base in astronomy and physics, and provide them with effective science instructional activities to use with their secondary school students. The 3-day workshops we offered have trained 30 secondary school teachers who will each go on to educate an estimated 100 secondary school students each year, potentially impacting 30,000 students over the next decade.  This is an important step towards developing the STEM  (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) pipeline of our nation, especially given the fact that Black/African American and  Hispanic/ Latinx students -- demographic groups greatly underrepresented in STEM fields -- make up 13% and ~53%, respectively, of K-12 public school students in Texas.
